title: Ultimate Comfort Food Chili (Hearty Recipe)

description: Warm up with this hearty chili recipe, great for chilly nights! Packed with flavor and easy to make, it's a family favorite.
ingredients: 1 can (15 oz) kidney beans, drained and rinsed
1 can (15 oz) black beans, drained and rinsed
instructions: In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the diced onion and sauté for 3-4 minutes until translucent.
Stir in the minced garlic and cook for an additional 1 minute until fragrant.
Add the ground beef to the pot, breaking it up with a spoon. Cook until browned, about 5-7 minutes. Drain excess fat if necessary.
Mix in the kidney beans, black beans, crushed tomatoes, chili powder, cumin, smoked paprika, salt, and pepper. Stir well to combine.
Pour in the beef broth and add the diced bell pepper and jalapeño. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer uncovered for 30-40 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. Serve hot, garnished with fresh cilantro.
tips: Here's the thing: To achieve the best flavor, use high-quality ground beef and allow the chili to simmer for longer if time permits. This enhances the depth of flavor. Avoid overcooking the garlic to prevent bitterness. For maximum flavor, consider using homemade beef broth. Store leftovers in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days, or freeze for up to 3 months. Reheat gently on the stove or in the microwave, adding a splash of water if needed to maintain consistency.

structured_content.content:
So I made chili last weekend and remembered why I love this recipe so much. It's just one of those things that makes the house smell amazing and fills everyone up. My husband ate two bowls before he even said anything. That's how you know it's good.

This isn't fancy chili. It's the kind you make when it's cold outside and you want something warm. Ground beef, beans, tomatoes, spices. Nothing complicated. Takes maybe an hour total and most of that is just letting it bubble on the stove.

What I like about it is you can make a big pot and eat it all week. Or freeze half for later when you don't feel like cooking. We usually have it with cornbread but honestly it's fine by itself too.

note.label: Why This Works
note.content:
• Ready in about an hour which is pretty fast for chili
  • Uses basic stuff you probably already have
  • Feeds a bunch of people without costing much
  • Tastes better the next day if you have leftovers
  • Easy to adjust if you like it spicier or milder

structured_content.content: First time I made this my kids looked at the beans and made faces. They thought it was going to be weird. But then they tried it and now they ask for it. My daughter even takes it for lunch sometimes in a thermos. She's 12 and usually won't eat anything I make so that's saying something.

structured_content.headline: What Goes In and What You Can Swap

structured_content.content:
The main thing is the ground beef. I get the 80/20 kind because it has enough fat to taste good but not so much that you're draining a ton off. You could use ground turkey if you want but it won't taste the same. Just being honest.

For beans I use both kidney and black beans. One can of each. You could do all one kind if that's what you have. Nobody's going to know the difference really. Just drain them good and rinse them or the chili gets too thick and weird.

The spices are chili powder, cumin, and smoked paprika. The smoked paprika is optional but it adds something nice. Makes it taste a little deeper. Don't skip the cumin though. That's important.

You need a big pot. Like a dutch oven or soup pot. Something that holds at least 5 quarts. And a wooden spoon for stirring. That's basically it for equipment.

upload.context: Fresh ingredients for chili including ground beef, beans, tomatoes, and spices arranged on a wooden cutting board, ready for cooking.

structured_content.content:
Before you start cooking get everything ready. Chop your onion, bell pepper, and jalapeño if you're using it. Mince the garlic. Open all your cans. Measure out the spices. This part takes maybe 10 minutes and makes everything easier later.

Heat the oil in your pot on medium. Throw in the onion and let it cook for a few minutes until it looks kinda see through. Add the garlic and stir it around for like a minute. Don't let it burn or it gets bitter and gross.

Now add the ground beef. Break it up with your spoon as it cooks. You want it all brown with no pink left. Takes maybe 5 or 7 minutes. If there's a lot of grease in the pot you can drain some off but I usually don't bother.

Dump in both kinds of beans, the crushed tomatoes, all your spices, the broth, and the peppers. Stir it all together. Turn the heat up until it starts bubbling then turn it way down to low. Let it simmer for 30 to 40 minutes. Stir it every now and then so nothing sticks to the bottom.

That's it. When it's thick and smells amazing it's done. Taste it and add more salt if you need to. Put some cilantro on top if you have it.

upload.context: Stirring the chili in a large pot on the stovetop, showcasing the rich, bubbling mixture with vibrant colors.

note.label: Don't Mess This Up
note.content:
• Keep it on low when it's simmering. You want little bubbles not big crazy ones.
  • Add the garlic after the onion cooks a bit. If you add it too early it burns.
  • You'll know it's done when it's thick and not watery. Should take 30 minutes at least.
  • Keep leftovers in a container with a lid in the fridge. Good for 4 days. Freezes great too for like 3 months.
  • When you reheat it add a little water if it got too thick in the fridge.

structured_content.content: Last time we had people over for dinner I made a double batch of this. Everyone kept going back for more. One of my friends asked for the recipe and then texted me later saying her husband loved it. That made me feel pretty good I'm not gonna lie.

So here's what you can add to make it even better. Fresh cilantro on top is really good. Makes it taste fresher. You could also use green onions if you don't like cilantro.

If you want it spicier just add more jalapeño or throw in some cayenne pepper. Like a quarter teaspoon at a time. You can always add more but you can't take it out once it's in there.

Toppings are where it's at though. Shredded cheese is obvious. Sour cream cools it down if it's too spicy. Avocado or guacamole is really good too. My husband likes to crush tortilla chips on top for crunch. Whatever you're into basically.

Cornbread is the classic thing to serve with chili. The sweet bread with the spicy chili just works. You can make it from scratch or use a box mix. Nobody cares as long as it's warm with butter.

I usually make a simple salad too. Just lettuce and tomatoes with ranch. Helps balance out how heavy the chili is. Green beans on the side are good too if you want a vegetable.

For drinks we do beer if it's the weekend. Or just water. Iced tea works too. Nothing fancy needed. And serve it in regular bowls. It doesn't need to look perfect. Just hot and ready to eat.

If you need it to be gluten free just check that your broth and canned stuff don't have any wheat in them. Most don't but some brands do weird things so just look at the labels.

For vegan chili skip the beef and use lentils instead. Or mushrooms chopped up small. Use vegetable broth instead of beef broth. It's different but still good in its own way.

You could also use ground turkey or chicken instead of beef. It'll be lighter and not as rich. Sometimes I do half beef and half turkey to save money and it still tastes fine.

upload.context: A steaming bowl of chili topped with fresh cilantro and served with crusty bread on a rustic table, ready to enjoy.

note.label: Tricks I've Learned
note.content:
• If you toast the chili powder in the pot for like 30 seconds before adding the liquid it tastes better. Just don't burn it.
  • Let the meat sit out for 15 minutes before cooking so it browns better instead of steaming.
  • Chop everything before you start cooking. Makes it way less stressful.
  • Squeeze lime juice on top right before eating. Really wakes up the flavors.

structured_content.content:
Making chili like this is pretty easy once you do it a couple times. It's one of those recipes where you can't really mess it up too bad. If it's a little different each time that's fine. Still tastes good.

Try it out and see what you think. You can change it around to fit what you like. Add more spice or less. Use different beans. Whatever works for you. Let me know how it goes if you make it.
